docs.lead_paragraph: Robert Downey Jr.'s very public struggle with addiction continues to illustrate the discrimination that less visible people with this chronic illness face on a daily basis (Mim Udovitch, Oct. 19). He can't get work on the new Woody Allen film because it costs too much to insure people with a medical history of addiction, even if they are in recovery. Yet research indicates that the structure and support provided by employment can actually improve treatment outcomes. Similarly, privately insured people with alcohol and other drug problems typically have to pay more out of their own pockets for treatment than those with other chronic medical conditions. Higher co-pays may discourage them from seeking treatment, leading to increases in other ad-diction-related health-care costs. Eric Goplerud Washington

headline.main: The Sobering Life of Robert Downey Jr.

docs.lead_paragraph: NOBODY expects employers to provide groceries, housing or clothing, but for odd historical reasons American employers have evolved into providers of health insurance. Nearly two-thirds of Americans under 65 rely on health coverage from an employer. Some of America's largest companies, maybe eager to level the playing field, favor requiring employers to provide insurance. But they have it backward. They should be advocating an end to employer-financed health coverage altogether.

headline.main: Why Do Employers Pay for Health Insurance, Anyway?

docs.abstract: Daniel Akst column calls for end to employer-financed health coverage; urges employers to push for national health coverage (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: REGINA CARTER has been cheating on her regular violin. So far, she's had two flings with another, older instrument, and she'll be having a third tomorrow night at Alice Tully Hall -- in public, no less. You can't exactly blame her for being disloyal, though. The instrument in question, known to connoisseurs as ''Il Cannone'' (''The Cannon'') because of its big, booming tone, is a priceless 1743 Guarneri belonging to the city of Genoa, Italy, to which it was bequeathed in 1840 by Nicolò Paganini, the greatest violin virtuoso in history. At 36, Ms. Carter is widely considered the finest jazz violinist of her generation, a hard-charging soloist whose precisely focused tone and graceful way with a ballad hint at her long years of classical training. She was the first jazz musician ever to be invited to use Paganini's violin, on which she performed in Genoa two years ago. She used it again 10 months later to record her latest CD, ''Paganini: After a Dream'' (Verve), and it has just been flown to New York City under armed guard especially for tomorrow's concert.

headline.main: Regina Carter Keeps in Touch With a 260-Year-Old Friend

docs.abstract: Profile of Regina Carter, first jazz violinist permitted to perform on Paganini's Guarneri violin; she will perform on it this week in New York concert; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT may sound trite, but it's true. The cure is likely to be as difficult as the disease for Westchester Medical Center, the 1,000-bed hospital in Valhalla. Like many other hospitals, Westchester Medical has found pain in the era of managed care and the huge upheavals in the health care industry. Complicating its condition is the need for the medical center to provide the kind of world-class cutting-edge care that has put it on the map while maintaining its legacy as the hospital of last resort, where the poor and the disadvantaged can go when no one else will take them. Beyond that, the hospital still struggles with the challenges it took on when it left its own safety net, its status as a county hospital in 1997, just as the storm clouds were gathering over the health care industry. And so, the hospital finds itself scrambling to close a $53 million budget gap from 2002, nearly 10 percent of its operating revenues.

headline.main: Hospital Scrambles to Close a Budget Gap

docs.abstract: Article on steps being taken by Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla, NY, to close $53 million budget gap left over from 2002; senior executive vice president Marilyn Slaatten says layoffs have been made, accounts receivable and supply distribution systems have been revamped and average length of patient stay has been reduced; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AN increasing number of unmarried couples who want to make their relationships a matter of public record may soon get the chance. In the next 10 days two more Long Island villages are scheduled to vote on virtually identical legislation that would set up domestic partner registries for their residents and employees. But serious questions remain about the value of such laws and their relevance. What exactly do they accomplish? Not much, in the view of Thomas Levin, the village attorney for North Hills, which unanimously approved a domestic partner registry last May. ''The law carries no legal weight,'' he said. ''In and of itself it doesn't offer any rights. How people seek to use it is up to them.''

headline.main: Two Villages to Vote On Partner Registries

docs.lead_paragraph: JOSEPH V. DORIA JR., the senior member of the state Assembly and keeper of its institutional memory, shifted in his chair when a visitor mentioned the word ''tragedy.'' While certainly overstated, it was the word Mr. Doria's friends and allies chose when describing what happened to him this summer. ''I don't know if it was a tragedy,'' he said. ''What is meant to be is meant to be.''

headline.main: For Joseph Doria, A Rare Election. He's Not Running.

docs.abstract: Article on Joseph Doria Jr, senior member of New Jersey state Assembly who lost his re-election bid in June's Democratic primary as result of bitter dispute between Jersey City Mayor Glenn Cunningham and Repr Robert Menendez over control of Hudson County Democratic Organization; Doria, first elected to Assembly in 1979, will remain mayor of Bayonne; photos (M)

headline.main: Doctors: Stop Complaining And Get Back to Work

docs.lead_paragraph: SAY you're critically ill. Your doctor says: ''I can write two prescriptions. One is not proven and may make your condition worse. The second has proven effective in every application. It's your choice.'' Over the last few weeks, newspapers have run articles and editorials on New Jersey's medical liability crisis. Some papers oppose the proven methods to fix the situation. They suggest that we cross our fingers and hope for the best. As support for their position, some cite as an expert Howard Weiss, formally of MIXX Insurance, who was kicked out of the insurance industry 12 years ago, never handled a claim in his life, has no data and now works for plaintiffs' attorneys. He has also testified before committees in the New Jersey Assembly.
docs.abstract: Medical Society of New Jersey president Mark Olesnicky Soapbox essay on New Jersey's medical liability crisis says doctors are frustrated at state Assembly's last-minute weakening of reform legislation; holds there is no evidence that bill would reduce insurance premiums; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Tricia Coultes, 33, of Lansing, Mich., was among the 20,000 participants in last year's Rock 'n' Roll Marathon in San Diego. She had no interest in running it, was unfamiliar with training methods and knew little about the sport. Coultes said her goal was to walk the marathon at a pace of 15 minutes a mile and enjoy the sights as part of a weekend vacation.
docs.abstract: Rise in number of entertainment-based marathons, like those that incorporate music events or encourage overweight participants, is leading to rise in number of marathon finishers; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Howard Dean's rivals for the Democratic nomination roundly attacked him on Saturday for telling an Iowa newspaper he wanted ''to be the candidate for guys with Confederate flags in their pickup trucks'' in defending his opposition to some gun control legislation. But Dr. Dean retorted that he had said much the same thing in front of largely black audiences months ago and suggested his opponents were flailing away at him in desperation.

headline.main: Rivals Attack Dean for Wooing 'Guys With Confederate Flags'

docs.abstract: Democratic presidential hopefuls criticize Howard Dean for his stance on gun control, and in particular his statement to Iowa newspaper that he wants to be 'candidate for guys with Confederate flags in their pickup trucks'; Sen John Kerry calls remark 'craven' and politics as usual (M)
